text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Bulgaria's president-elect Petar Stoyanov was sworn into office by the parliament speaker Blagovest Sendov at an official ceremony in parliament on Sunday.

-- Bulgaria's outgoing Interior Minister Nikolai Dobrev, nominated by the ruling Socialists to form a new cabinet, submitted to the party's executive bureau a draft anti-crisis programme aimed at financial stabilisation and crackdown on corruption and crime.

-- Belgium's Solvay SA chemical producer was expected this week to transfer the second tranche of $30 million out of a total of $160 million it paid for 60 percent of Bulgaria's soda ash producer Sodi Devnya, Bulgaria's Privatisation Agency said.

-- Bulgaria could pass all the bills necessary for the introduction of a currency board system by mid-June if early parliamentary elections are held before that, Bulgaria's main opposition Union of Democratic Forces leader Ivan Kostov said.
In this way Bulgaria could avoid default on its foreign debt payments due in July, Kostov said.

-- Bulgaria's state owned Expressbank could extend up to $125,000 five-year loans to Bulgaria's small- and medium sized local businesses under the European Union's Phare programme, Balkan news agency quoted a bank official as saying.
-- Negotiations for the sale of Bulgaria's GSM opperator Mobiltel to the Italian Stet company were expected to be finalised by the end of the week, an official said.

-- Bulgaria's biggest oil refinery Neftohim might be blocked today by striking workers after Sunday's protests were postponed because of the swearing-in ceremony of Bulgaria's president-elect Petar Stoyanov, a trade union official said.
